Ahupūngao Physics

Explore the way our world is put together and how it works. Study the universe from the smallest parts of an atom to the cosmos.

Explore subject

You want to know about:

study

You come from:

  • Apply now
  • Contact us
  • Stay updated
On this page:

Physics drives technology

Physics is the problem-solving engine behind the new tech industries that are reinventing New Zealand’s economy. Learn to create theoretical models that fuel real innovation. You’ll develop the skills to help to create cutting edge technologies like next-generation solar panels, or to model climate change more accurately than ever before.

The mechanics of the universe

When you study Physics at Te Herenga Waka—Victoria University of Wellington, you’ll discover the components and forces that make up our universe. You’ll be learning from world-leading specialists in exciting new areas like biophysics, astrophysics, and spintronics—visiting their laboratories and participating in their research.

Learn about orbital mechanics and develop an understanding of how objects move around the galaxy. Explore electromagnetism, the science behind radio-based technologies as diverse as mobile phones, microwaves, and medical scanners. Discover thermal physics, and build an understanding of the theoretical framework behind climate change.

Finally, you’ll delve into quantum mechanics and learn to create models of the smallest processes in the universe, those between atoms and molecules—models that can, in turn, help us to better understand tiny entities like coronaviruses.

1.75 billion

Estimated revenue of the NZ space economy, 2018-2019

Wellington—New Zealand’s technology hub

You’ll build connections for your future through the University’s relationships with Wellington’s technology and innovation community.

You’ll have the opportunity to learn from and work with leading researchers at institutes like NIWA and the Robinson and MacDiarmid research institutes, as well as forging relationships with the city’s start-ups and growing tech industry.

Need help? Download a brochure

“It’s a place of state-of-the-art fundamental research, fully equipped laboratories, lecturers who are experts in their fields, and an environment that nurtures the scientists-to-be”.

Aleksa Djorovic

Bachelor of Science student in Physics and Chemistry

Full story

Learning through curiosity

Physics is collaborative

Modern physics is all about working as a team—and our approach to teaching reflects this. You’ll get close support from teaching staff and other students throughout your study. Physics at Wellington has a whānau approach where it’s safe to make mistakes as you’re learning, where you know the staff and the staff know you.

We’re housed in a bright and open building, with plenty of common spaces where you can learn collaboratively.

Study options

Bachelor of Science - BSc

Physics Major
Duration: 3 years (360 points)
Intensity: Full time or part time
Location: Wellington campuses. This programme can be started online if you are outside New Zealand.
Key dates: Apply by 01 Dec 2021 to start studying 28 Feb 2022
Apply by 01 May 2022 to start studying 11 Jul 2022
Level of study: Undergraduate
Cost:
NZ$34,521.00 for the full programme. Approximately AF ؋1,911,176.97 at current exchange rates per 120 points
Entry: Achieve the International Baccalaureate Diploma, or three GCE Advanced Level passes at C grade, or equivalent. You may also be required to demonstrate your proficiency in English.
Useful secondary school subjects: Sciences and Maths

Major requirements

In addition to the degree requirements [link to degree page], to graduate with a BSc with a major in Physics you will need to include:

Four courses at 100 level:
  • Either (Calculus 1B (MATH 142) and Algebra (MATH 151)) or (Engineering Mathematics Foundations (ENGR 121) and B+ or better in Engineering Mathematics with Calculus (ENGR 122))
  • Physics 1A (PHYS 114)
  • Physics 1B (PHYS 115)
Five courses at 200 level:
  • Multivariable Calculus (MATH 243)

Three courses from:

  • Quantum Mechanics and Kinetic Theory (PHYS 241)
  • Electromagnetism I (PHYS 242)
  • Classical Mechanics and Relativity (PHYS 243)
  • Methods of Experimental Physics (PHYS 245)

One further course from:

  • EEEN 201-204
  • PHYS 201-259
Four courses at 300 level:
  • Electromagnetism II (PHYS 304)
  • Thermal Physics (PHYS 305)
  • Quantum Physics (PHYS 307)
  • Solid State and Nuclear Physics (PHYS 309)

Eligibility

Requirements for domestic/international students who studied in

  • University Entrance, or to meet the requirements of another admission type
  • Check your admission type - Check your admission type

Prerequisites for core courses

PHYS 114 and PHYS 115 are core courses. Depending on your secondary school qualification, you will need to meet one of the following prerequisites:

NCEA:

14 NCEA Level 3 credits in Physics, and 14 NCEA Level 3 credits in Mathematics including:

  • 3.6 Differentiation (91578)
  • 3.7 Integration (91579)

Note: 18 NCEA Level 3 standards in both Mathematics and Physics are strongly recommended.

Or one of the following:

  • 1 externally assessed standard with Excellence in both NCEA Level 3 Mathematics and Physics

or

  • 2 externally assessed standards with Merit in both NCEA Level 3 Mathematics and Physics
  • 2 externally assessed standards with Excellence in NCEA Level 3 Calculus
  • An equivalent background in Mathematics or Physics.
Cambridge International examinations:

A minimum of D at A level or A at AS level (or better) in both Physics and Mathematics in the A level Cambridge International Examinations.

International Baccalaureate:

A minimum of 4 at HL or 6 at SL (or better) in the International Baccalaureate grade scale in both Physics and Mathematics.

Achieving outstanding results

If you achieved outstanding high school or scholarship results in a physics and mathematics topic, you may be able to enrol directly in some 200-level physics courses. Contact the School of Chemical and Physical Sciences (scps@vuw.ac.nz) in mid-February or as soon as you get your results to find out if this applies to you.

Pathways to Physics

If you don’t meet the requirements, there are physics and mathematics courses that you can take to gain entry to PHYS 114 and PHYS 115. Contact the Faculty of Science Student and Academic Services Office (science-faculty@vuw.ac.nz) to find out more.

Scientific skills for life

A degree in Physics will help you develop skills for life. You’ll learn how to identify a problem, come up with a theory to explain it, and then test that theory rigorously. You’ll develop your confidence in mathematics and learn to write computer programs. And as making new discoveries is a team effort, you’ll learn to collaborate with others.

Working from home

In an uncertain world, it helps to know that your learning is supported wherever you are. If you’re not able to work on campus, you can access video lectures, live online tutorials, and remote lab sessions.

Find out more about studying remotely

Improve your writing

Writing is a key part of science. Throughout your degree study, you’ll develop the skills to write for a range of audiences. Whether it’s a lab report for an academic audience or a presentation to a sponsor, you’ll be able to share your discoveries and deliver your message clearly.

If you’d like extra help with your writing, we can help: Student learning

Your course of study

Building your degree

At university, you’re in charge of your course of study.

Find out how to put your degree together and learn about the differences between majors and minors, conjoint degrees and double majors.

Learning through curiosity

Workload

To achieve an average grade in a course, you should plan to spend a minimum of 10 hours per point. So, for one 15-point course you should allow for 150 hours of work over the trimester. That’s about 10–12 hours per week for each course, including lectures, tutorials, labs, and exam periods.

If you are studying full-time, you are likely to take six to eight courses over the year. Plan to balance your study, work, and life with this workload in mind.

Choosing course

If you are taking a three-year degree, it’s a good idea to look ahead and think about what you might like to study in your second and third years, as your chosen major or majors may have specific prerequisites for advanced-level courses.

To add variety and depth to your degree, you might take some courses from outside the sciences.

Find out more

Funding your study

Scholarships

Scholarships are awarded to hundreds of students each year and can help with living and accommodation costs at the University’s halls of residence.

Take a look at school leaver scholarships, and search our scholarships database to see if there’s one that’s right for you.

  • School leaver scholarships
  • Scholarships database

Managing your finances

Get advice to help you control your money so that it doesn’t control you. Take a look at our financial resources

  • Financial survival

or meet with a student finance advisor for budgeting advice and support.

  • Meet with a student finance adviser

Work while you study

Most students find that they need to support their study with part time work.

At the University, you’ll find opportunities to work in your field of interest while you study for your degree.

  • Employment opportunities

Chemistry

Chemistry underlies all the functions of the human body, the buildings we live and work in, the energy we generate and consume, and the air we breathe.
